title: Welcome!
text:
On this website you will find all sorts of information about me and my various interests. I hope you find something here that you also enjoy.
If after exploring this website you have any questions, requests, comments, or offers, please feel free to send them to me via email at bchristman@umc.edu.

title: About Me
text: On this page you find my answers to some questions that I am commonly asked. If there are any other questions that you think I should add to this page, please email me and let me know!

title: Installing R and RStudio and Getting Oriented
text:
The first step to downloading and installing R is to go to this link: https://cran.wustl.edu
Once there, you will find a page which contains the following content.

Select either of the links that I have outlined above. If you have a Mac select the macOS option, if you have a Windows device select the Windows option.
Once you have done so, you will find a page which contains the following content.

Click on the link in the top left to download the latest version of R for your operating system.
Go through the steps for the installation (the pop-up will walk you through this process). My recommendation is to save R to your Downloads folder.

title: Installing R and RStudio and Getting Oriented
text:
Download and Install RStudio
The first step to downloading and installing RStudio is to go to this link: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Once there scroll down until you see the following content.

Note: I am on a Mac, which is why the download says “Download RStudio Desktop for Mac”.
Click on the Download button to download RStudio. Go through the steps for the installation (the pop-up will walk you through this process). Make sure to save RStudio in the same location that you saved R.

title: Installing R and RStudio and Getting Oriented
text:
Using R and RStudio
Now that you have both R and RStudio installed on your computer, you can begin programming! To do so, open RStudio by clicking on the RStudio icon now on your desktop or by searching for it in your computer’s files.
Once RStudio has opened you should see the following screen.

There should be three widnows, which are:

Console - shown on the left. You can type code here to complete simple tasks or perform basic debugging.
Environment/History - shown on the top right. This will display the variables which you have stored in the program as well as all code you have executed in this session.
Files/Plots/Packages/Help/Viewer - Shown on the bottom right. This shows you all the files on your computer, any plots or outputs you have made in this session, and the R packages downloaded onto your computer. This section also offers a search function for all of R’s functions and packages.

This information will make much more sense to you as you begin to work in R. So, let’s get started.

title: Installing R and RStudio and Getting Oriented
text:
Opening a New Document
To open and create a new document, click the button (located at the top left corner of your screen) that I have circled below.

This will prompt a drop down menu to appear. Take a look at all the different options presented to you. I recommend selecting the “R Markdown…” option and then simply hitting “OK” in the following pop-up window.
Alternatively, Posit (the company overseeing RStudio) has recently released another publishing system called Quarto. It is a lot like RStudio, but offers some additional and pretty cool capabilities/features. If you are interested, you can download Quarto here: https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/ If you decide to use Quarto, select the “Quarto Document…” option instead of the “R Markdown…” option.
Now that the document has been opened, let’s get to programming!

title: Research
text: No matching items

title: About Me
section: What do you do for a living?
text:
What do you do for a living?
I am a third-year doctoral student in Biostatistics and Data Science at the University of Mississippi Medical Center. I am employed as a graduate assistant in the Department of Preventive Medicine through a grant funded by the Mississippi Department of Education for my work with the Mississippi School-based Telehealth Program. Additionally, I am employed as an independent statistical consultant for the Mississippi Public Health Institute.

title: About Me
section: What do you do in your free time?
text:
What do you do in your free time?
You can generally find me wandering aimlessly while birdwatching, rolling out pasta dough, performing on the saxophone, struggling to breath while running, reading statistics books/papers, eating, losing in chess, cuddling with my cats (Neville and Luna), or out and about with my partner, Athena.

title: About Me
text:
Do you do anything fun?
No.

title: About Me
section: Why did you go into biostatistics?
text: Why did you go into biostatistics?

title: About Me
section: It seems that a lot of your research is focused on adolescents; is there a reason for that?
text:
It seems that a lot of your research is focused on adolescents; is there a reason for that?
Yes, I intentionally decided to dedicate my research efforts to adolescents and children, more broadly. I believe, for several reasons, that children are understudied relative to their adult counterparts and that this should not be the case. I also believe that as a researcher I should try to make the world a better place for future generations. In my eyes, there is no better way to do that than by trying to keep children happy and healthy. Through my research I try to identify the specific challenges facing children, so that others may better be able to remedy them.

title: About Me
text:
Are you open to opportunities?
I am always open to new experiences. Thus, if you are interested in collaborating with me, having me deliver a presentation/seminar, or hiring me, please feel free to reach out!

title: Professional Materials
text:
On this page you will find all my professional materials. I will add documents as I complete them.


Curriculum Vitae


Personal Statement from Graduate School Application

title: About Me
section: It seems that a lot of your research is focused on Mississippi; is there a reason for this?
text:
It seems that a lot of your research is focused on Mississippi; is there a reason for this?
Yes, much of my work is focused on Mississippi because I live there.

title: About Me
section: It seems that a lot of your research is focused on Mississippi; are you from there?
text:
It seems that a lot of your research is focused on Mississippi; are you from there?
No, I am not from Mississippi. I have only lived in Mississippi for the last couple of years while attending graduate school, but I have thoroughly enjoyed my time here. I am originally from Schwenksville, PA, which is a small suburb of Philadelphia. I lived there until I moved to Memphis, TN to attend Rhodes College.
While I am not originally from Mississippi, it is the focus of much of my research because there are many strong, clear health challenges that face the state, and I want to do the best that I can to help address them.

title: About Me
text:
What are your career goals?
Upon graduating from my PhD program, if fate so decrees, I intend to do a postdoctoral fellowship. This is because I would like to gain more experience and further develop my academic interests prior to applying for faculty positions. I, ultimately, would like to be a professor because I thoroughly enjoy teaching and passing on my love for statistics and science to others. If you have any advice for me on how to best accomplish either of these goals, please reach out!

title: Ultramarathon Running
text: On April 22nd, 2023 I ran the Fondren Urban Ultra in Jackson, MS. The premise of this race was very simple; complete as many 5k laps as you could in a 12-hour period.

title: About Me
section: What are you interested in studying?
text:
What are you interested in studying?
My research interests are quite varied, as you could probably gather. I am broadly interested in research in longitudinal studies/methods, survey methodology, missing data methods, cardiometabolic health, psychology, pediatrics, and the intersections of each of these topics.

title: About Me
section: What areas are you interested in for research?
text:
What areas are you interested in for research?
My research interests are quite varied, as you could probably gather. I am broadly interested in research in longitudinal studies/methods, survey methodology, missing data methods, cardiometabolic health, psychology, pediatrics, and the intersections of each of these topics.

title: Ultramarathon Running
text:
On April 22nd, 2023 I ran the Fondren Urban Ultra in Jackson, MS. The premise of this race was very simple; complete as many 5k laps as you could in a 12-hour period.
Prior to this race, I had never run further than a half marathon (13.1 miles). Disclaimer, this wasn’t a great idea.
My gameplan for the race was straightforward; stop for a few minutes after every lap to refuel, use the restroom, and stretch.
With this strategy, I was able to run 34.1 miles in around 8 hours and 20 minutes.

title: The Reason I Run
text: For those who look

title: Why Biostatistics?
text:
“Why would you want to do that?”
Funnily enough, this is the response I most often get when I tell people what I do. It is usually said with bewilderment, accompanied by some other classics, such as “That sounds horrible!” or “I always hated math”, and topped off with the deafening desire to move on to a new topic.
To be clear, I completely understand why most people feel this way and do not blame them for their responses. Biostatistics is a fairly difficult topic to relate to, especially if you are just hearing about it for the first time. And let’s be honest, it is almost impossible to hear someone say “I’m getting a PhD in biostatistics and data science”, or any of its variations, and not think they are just a wee bit full of themselves.
With all that being said, I would like to attempt to make biostatistics more relatable. So, I am going to share my motivation for choosing this field and why I absolutely love what I do.
Before I start, I would like to share an article that was just written by my university that discusses my journey to biostatistics and Mississippi. (The irony is not lost on me; I realize that sharing this does me no good in trying to combat the pomposity claims).
Now, let’s get started!

title: Reading Tracker
text:
On this page you will find all the papers and books that I have read since I started tracking on July 16, 2023. The purpose of this is to encourage both myself and others to read more.
Please note that the ratings I provide are strictly my personal opinion and I mean no ill will if I rate something of yours poorly. Additionally, if I rate something well that does not mean that I am endorsing the authors; it simply means that I enjoyed reading their work or found it useful.
